availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: Ohio Congressman and U.S. Army general. Native of Franklin, Ohio. Son of William Cortenus Schenck. Graduated from Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, with a Bachelor of Arts in 1827 and a Master of Arts in 1830. Professor at Miami University from 1827 to 1829. Admitted to the Ohio bar in January 1831. Member of Ohio House of Representatives from 1841 to 1842. U.S. Congressman from 1843 to 1851. U.S. envoy and minister to Brazil from March 12, 1851, to October 8, 1853. Brigadier general from May 17, 1861, to August 30, 1862.Major general from August 30, 1862, to December 5, 1863. U.S. Congressman from March 4, 1863, to January 5, 1871.

ab.bibl:
Fred B. Joyner, “Robert Cumming Schenck, First Citizen and Statesman of The Miami Valley,” _Ohio Archaeological and Historical Quarterly 58(July 1949): 286-88.
“Ill But Five Days: Gen. Robert C. Schenck Dies of Pneumonia—His Career as Congressman, Soldier, and Diplomat was a Remarkable One,” Belmont Chronicle (St. Clairsville, Ohio), March 27, 1890.
Andrew, R. Dodge, Biographical Directory of the United States Congress, 1774-2005: the Continental Congress, September 5, 1774, to October 21, 1788, and the Congress of the United States, from the First through the One Hundred Eighth Congresses, March 4, 1789, to January 3, 2005, Inclusive (Washington, DC: US Gov. Print. Off., 2005), 1871.
“Robert Cumming Schenck,” U.S. Department of State, Office of the Historian, accessed April 4, 2018, https://history.state.gov/departmenthistory/people/schenck-robert-cumming.
